key_points: President Biden hosted the Global COVID-19 Summit virtually alongside the UN General Assembly, focusing on ending the pandemic and improving global health security.
The summit's objectives include vaccinating the world, saving lives now, building back better, and calling the world to account through measurable targets.
Biden announced the U.S. will donate an additional half-billion Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccines to low and lower-middle-income countries, bringing the total commitment to over 1.1 billion doses.
The U.S. plans to provide additional funding through USAID and the CDC to enhance global vaccine readiness and delivery.
The U.S. International Development Finance Corporation (DFC) is committing over $383 million in political risk insurance to facilitate global vaccine shipments.
Investments have been made in vaccine manufacturing facilities in Africa and India to boost production capacity for developing countries.
The U.S. calls for expanding global and regional production of COVID-19 vaccines and enhancing transparency about vaccine availability.
Support for a temporary waiver of intellectual property protections under the WTO's TRIPS Agreement for COVID-19 vaccines has been reiterated.
Nearly $1.4 billion will be provided by USAID and CDC to mitigate COVID-19 impacts and strengthen health systems.
The summit emphasizes global cooperation and urgency in addressing the pandemic and preparing for future health crises.
